awd_titl_txt: RAPID: Distancing & Digital Information in the Face of COVID-19
awd_abstract_narration:
The COVID-19 pandemic poses arguably the most formidable set of health and broader societal challenges of the 21st century to people around the world. This project studies the judgements, perceptions, and behaviors that result from different types, quality, and amount of digital information and different social distancing restrictions in a high-stress context of spatial distancing over a prolonged period during the COVID-19 crisis. Such understanding can help us develop better strategies—including shaping the content and timeliness of online and offline communication of public policies—to respond more effectively to future large-scale crises that also may impose restrictions on the day-to-day, face-to-face human interactions that comprise the norm for modern society.

As large numbers of people cut off spatial ties and limit their mobility in the COVID-19 pandemic, the demand for digital media has increased, not only to increase understanding of health and economic impacts and to reduce anxiety and uncertainty, but also to compensate for the severance of in person social interactions. This information comes from different sources, changes over time, and varies in quality, credibility, and timeliness. The research team hypothesizes that the nature of the information consumed and intensity of immersion in the digital environment during the COVID-19 pandemic can prompt different construals of the pandemic and thereby shape risk preferences and behaviors. The team investigates these perceptions, preferences, choices, and behavioral responses to spatial distancing public policies through a multiple wave, online panel study of 400 residents of the Washington-Arlington-Alexandria metropolitan area. The research uses construal level theory by empirically distinguishing between the spatial and psycho-social dimensions of the construct of psychological distancing and calibrating the psychological impacts of immersion in online environments during a period of limited in-person interactions. The team investigates how digital media and technology consumption influence construal level and how the interaction of these two factors shape individuals’ risk perceptions, attitudes, and behaviors over time. Our research thus moves beyond simplistic explanations of the direct linkage between psychological distance, construal level, and judgments and decisions to a more nuanced understanding of interactions between construal mindsets and overload, stress, and fear.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit: Our research stretches the literature on decision making under uncertainty, which typically assumes both that the choices people make reflect their priorities in life and attitudes toward risk (i.e., risk averse/neutral/loving) and that these risk preference and priorities remain static over the timeline of events. At the onset of the COVID-19 pandemic, individuals who experienced the pandemic as psychologically distant were less risk averse in terms of certain health-related risks. Individuals who experienced the pandemic as psychologically close were more risk averse in terms of their choices of government policies related to closures and social distancing policies such as ban on gatherings, closure of businesses and schools. Individuals who reside in denser metropolitan areas experience lower levels of psychological distance (that is, they feel more psychologically close to the pandemic) compared to people who live in less dense, suburban areas. This provides the first study of its kind to describe the spatial correlates of psychological distance. We also are finding differences in risk perceptions and priorities and behavioral intentions in metropolitan regions based on when these cities decided to open up their economies, and urban/suburban/rural parts of the same metropolitan and similar environments across cities.  We are also finding a significant impact of self reported pandemic related news consumption on feelings about government policies related to COVID, behaviors before and since the pandemic, perceived risk of being infected with COVID, risk aversion levels, and psychological distance levels.

Our research moves beyond simplistic explanations of the direct linkage between psychological distance, construal level, and judgments and decisions to a more nuanced understanding of interactions between construal mindsets, spatial, and informational dimensions. Our work also extends the literature to accommodate spatial distancing resulting from public policies that severely limit face-to-face interaction.

Broader Impacts:  Our study offers to increase understanding of the judgements, perceptions, and behaviors that result from different types, quality, and amount of digital information and different social distancing restrictions in a high-stress context of spatial distancing over a prolonged period during the COVID-19 crisis. Such understanding can help us develop better strategies, including shaping the content and timeliness of online and offline communication of public policies, to respond more effectively to future large-scale crises that also may impose restrictions on the day-to-day, face-to-face human interactions that comprise the norm for modern society.
